    Rubber Off-Gassing and VOC Emissions by Material Type: Choosing the Right Elastomer

    In sensitive applications—automotive interiors, medical devices, aerospace cabins, electronics enclosures, and vacuum systems—rubber off-gassing and VOC emissions can be just as important as tensile strength or compression set.

  • Nov 29, 2025

    How Rubber Tooling Works: An Engineer’s Guide to Molds, Inserts, Cavities, and Parting Lines

    When designing a new rubber part, one of the biggest sources of confusion for engineers is tooling—how molds are made, how cavities are shaped, and what limitations are imposed by rubber molding processes. Good tooling design impacts everything from part quality and flash control to cycle time and long-term mold durability.

  • Nov 28, 2025

    Compression Set in Rubber: What It Is and How to Reduce It in Long-Term Sealing Applications

    Rubber seals are expected to maintain their shape, elasticity, and sealing force for years—sometimes decades. But over time, many elastomers permanently deform under constant compression or temperature, leading to leaks, pressure loss, or total seal failure.

  • Nov 27, 2025

    Understanding Rubber Hardness (Shore A): How to Select the Right Durometer for Your Application

    Selecting the correct rubber hardness, or durometer, is one of the most important decisions in designing a rubber part. Whether you’re developing a seal, suspension bushing, vibration isolator, or molded gasket, the hardness of the elastomer affects how the part compresses, seals, flexes, absorbs vibration, and ultimately survives long-term use.

  • Nov 26, 2025

    How to Choose the Right Rubber Compound for Outdoor Applications: UV, Ozone, and Weathering Resistance Explained

    Rubber components used outdoors face far harsher conditions than those in controlled indoor environments. Sunlight, ozone, moisture, temperature swings, and atmospheric pollutants can all break down elastomers—leading to cracking, hardening, and premature failure.

  • Nov 25, 2025

    Injection vs. Transfer Molding for Small Precision Rubber Seals in Medical Devices

    When developing small, precision rubber seals for medical devices, the molding process is just as important as the compound. Choosing between injection molding and transfer molding affects part accuracy, flash levels, material waste, assembly fit, and long-term reliability.

  • Nov 15, 2025

    Designing Custom Rubber Bushings for Off-Road Suspension: Durometer, Void Patterns, and Torsional Behavior

    Rubber bushings may look simple, but in off-road suspension systems they play a critical role in handling, ride quality, NVH reduction, and component longevity. Unlike on-road vehicles, off-road builds subject bushings to high angular displacement, grit abrasion, torsional loading, and extreme compression cycles.

  • Nov 14, 2025

    Designing Rubber Seals for Chemical Resistance in Hydraulic and Fuel Systems

    In hydraulic, pneumatic, and fuel systems, rubber seals are critical to reliability. A single seal failure can lead to leaks, downtime, contamination, or even complete system failure.
    One of the biggest challenges in these environments is chemical resistance — the ability of rubber materials to resist swelling, softening, or cracking when exposed to aggressive fluids.

  • Nov 13, 2025

    How to Reduce Flash and Improve Tolerances in Rubber Injection Molded Parts

    When it comes to rubber injection molding, one of the most common challenges manufacturers face is flash — the thin excess layer of material that forms along parting lines or mold seams.
    While it might seem minor, flash can lead to functional issues, interfere with assembly, or require costly secondary trimming operations.

  • Nov 13, 2025

    How Temperature Cycling Affects Rubber Part Lifespan

    Rubber components used in industrial, automotive, and outdoor environments are constantly exposed to temperature swings — sometimes from sub-zero mornings to scorching operating temperatures within minutes. These repeated changes, known as temperature cycling, cause rubber to expand, contract, harden, soften, and eventually break down. If your rubber parts are failing earlier than expected, temperature cycling is often a major contributor.

  • Nov 12, 2025

    Why Your Rubber-to-Metal Bond Keeps Failing (and How to Fix It)

    Rubber-to-metal bonding is one of the toughest challenges in molding. When done right, the result is a single, unified component that can handle vibration, load, and stress for years. But when the bond fails, it’s almost always catastrophic — parts separate, mounts crack, and equipment breaks down.

  • Nov 12, 2025

    How to Design Rubber Vibration Mounts That Last in Harsh Industrial Environments

    When industrial equipment runs day after day under heavy loads, vibration is inevitable. But when vibration mounts fail — cracking, delaminating, or hardening — they can cause serious damage to machinery, reduce product lifespan, and increase downtime.

  • Nov 12, 2025

    Custom EPDM Gaskets for Outdoor Electrical Enclosures: What to Know Before You Order

    If you design or maintain outdoor electrical enclosures, you already know how critical the gasket is.
    It’s the unsung hero that keeps out water, dust, UV radiation, and temperature extremes — ensuring reliability year after year.

    Rubber vs. Plastic: When to Choose Rubber for Your Parts

    When designing a new product, one of the first decisions engineers face is choosing between rubber and plastic. Both materials can be molded into complex shapes, both are cost-effective, and both can be tailored to a wide range of applications.

  • Nov 10, 2025

    Understanding Durometer — How Rubber Hardness Affects Performance

    When designing custom rubber parts, durometer is one of the most important — and often overlooked — properties to get right. The durometer of a rubber compound determines how soft or hard it feels, how it compresses, and how it performs under load.

  • Nov 9, 2025

    How Rubber Is Bonded to Metal

    Rubber-to-metal bonding is a critical process in manufacturing durable components used in everything from automotive mounts to industrial vibration isolators. It combines the flexibility and sealing power of rubber with the strength and stability of metal — creating parts that can handle stress, temperature changes, and harsh environments.

  • Nov 8, 2025

    How Tooling Design Affects the Quality of Rubber Molded Parts

    When it comes to rubber injection molding, the quality of the final part is determined long before the first shot is made — it starts with the tooling design. A well-designed mold ensures consistent dimensions, smooth surface finishes, and efficient production. Poor tooling design, on the other hand, can lead to flash, voids, uneven curing, or premature wear. Understanding how tooling affects part quality is key to achieving reliable, high-performance results.

  • Nov 7, 2025

    Oil-Resistant Rubber Materials: What to Use for Automotive or Industrial Seals

    When designing seals, gaskets, or hoses that come in contact with fuels, lubricants, or hydraulic fluids, oil resistance becomes one of the most important material properties. Not all rubber compounds are created equal — exposure to oils and hydrocarbons can cause swelling, softening, or complete material failure if the wrong compound is used.

  • Nov 6, 2025

    How to Improve Durability in Industrial Rubber Seals and Gaskets

    Rubber seals and gaskets are the unsung heroes of industrial systems — keeping fluids contained, machinery protected, and equipment running smoothly. When these components fail, the result can be costly downtime, safety hazards, and even product recalls. That’s why improving the durability of industrial rubber seals and gaskets is one of the smartest investments any manufacturer can make.

    EPDM vs Nitrile vs Silicone: Which Rubber Material Should You Use?

    Choosing the right rubber compound is one of the most important steps in creating a reliable, high-performing molded part. Each material has its strengths and weaknesses depending on the environment, temperature, and chemical exposure. Among the most common options are EPDM, Nitrile (Buna-N), and Silicone. Here’s how they compare — and how to choose the right one for your application.

Understanding how temperature, chemical exposure, and UV radiation affect rubber longevity can help you design parts that perform reliably for years instead of months.

    The automotive industry relies heavily on rubber components to ensure vehicles perform reliably and safely. From engine mounts to door seals, custom-molded rubber parts are essential to comfort, safety, and performance. But designing these components for modern vehicles requires more than just choosing a flexible material — it demands attention to temperature, chemical exposure, noise reduction, and manufacturability.
